title: What are the best free websites for learning English? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi there, In order to learn English fast and effectively, I’ve listed some resources and tips to target your listening, reading AND speaking. Some of the sites below are not websites targeted for language learning, however you can still learn a great deal from them. At the end of the day, the best way to learn English is to learn to use the digital resources available in everyday life and use it, whether these are websites, podcasts, videos or more. I really hope this list helps you on your language learning journey! 1. Memorize 10 New Words a Day for 100 Days Here are some ways to do this: Take a look at the Mnemonic Dictionary, and use memory aids to remember words: Fun and easy way to build your vocabulary!  An additional option is to check out our free learn a language challenge. We created this free challenge after looking into studies on the effectiveness of learning the most common words in English and other languages. Research has shown that by memorizing 1,000 of the most common words in any language will help you become familiar with 85%+ of the oral language.  2. Read Children Books On Kindle in English You may have to leave the ego at the door before reading children books in English. But you’ll be rewarded for it, as children books are perfectly designed for English beginners to master their vocabulary and grammar skills.  3. Watch your favorite show on Netflix with English Audio or Subtitles Since you’re already spending your weekends and nights ‘Netflixing and Chilling‘, why not challenge yourself to learn English online as well? It’s likely that your favorite shows are already streaming in English, so you just have to choose whether you want English subtitles or no subtitles. As a rule of thumb, if you’re: A beginner English speaker: watch with English subtitles and audio in your native languageAn intermediate English speaker: watch with English audio and English subtitlesAn advanced English speaker: watch with just English audio 4. Work with a private language teacher online using Rype If this is your first time hearing about us, you can treat Rype as your personal trainer for languages. We’ve helped thousands of students around the world learn English online and other popular languages such as Spanish and French. Our method is using the power of live 1-on-1 video lessons and daily immersion, where our students can book lessons every single day with our handpicked professional language teachers. You can redeem your first two weeks for free on our website.  5. Follow the top language bloggers online The best language blogs are the ones that are written in the language you’re trying to learn. Luckily for us, that’s easy to find for learning English. When it comes to fun and effectiveness, we love recommending creative English blogs like ESL Hip Hop. It takes the popular genre of hip hop music and celebrities, and integrates it into learning English at the same time. If hip hop isn’t your thing, you can take a look at our complete list of top language blogs online and find the ones best fit for you.  6. Memorize the chorus of your favorite English song Music is one of the most powerful ways to learn English or any foreign language. You can start by memorizing the chorus of your favorite song, and singing along while you’re working, doing laundry, or jamming with your friends. Once you have the hang of it, challenge yourself to memorize the entire song using lyric tools like Song Lyrics & Knowledge. Don’t worry about understanding the meaning of the lyrics in the beginning. In fact, even native English speakers don’t understand half of what artists are saying in their songs!  7. Play Scrabble online with friends Scrabble is a classic game when it comes to improving your vocabulary skills. While it may feel like a piece of cake playing in your native language, it’s a completely different ball game when you play it in English. Gather some friends that are also looking to improve their English vocabulary skills, and play together online or host a game at your place this weekend! Pogo: SCRABBLE  8. Be entertained by watching popular English Youtubers  (Watch it now: How to Argue - Philosophical Reasoning: Crash Course Philosophy #2) There are an endless list of English YouTube vloggers that you can follow to learn English online. You do want to make sure that you’re following someone that: Is aligned to the type of English you want to speak (if you want to live in the US, watch US vloggers, etc.)Speaks clearly, professionally, and has a channel around talking to his or her audienceCaptures your attention and creates videos around a topic of your interest (i.e. Travel, Sports, Business, etc.)9. Get inspired watching the best TED Talks in English TED is a global event that brings together the world’s top leaders, influencers, and speakers into one room. Previous speakers include Bill Gates, Tony Robbins, Ray Kurzweil, and more. Due to the calibre of these speakers, you may need to look up some of the words that are used during their presentation.  10. Listen to an English podcast on your way to work Podcasts are an effective and efficient way to learn English while on-the-go. Keep in mind that you’ll likely be performing another task while you’re listening, so you want to pay close attention. You can either choose to listen to popular podcasts that are in English or specific language learning podcasts that can help you learn English. Here are some great English podcasts, but a quick search on a topic of your interest will give you more tailored searches Serial: Season TwoAll Ears English PodcastMonocle 24: Culture with Robert Bound by Monocle on iTunesThe Inquiry - BBC World ServiceThe Media Podcast with Olly MannInterested and want to read more on this topic? Check out our blog post on Rype Magazine to see the complete list! Hope this helps! [Disclaimer: I currently work for Rype]

This question is pretty broad, but there are many great resources available for free that will help improve all aspects of your English (reading, writing, speaking, listening). My list may be a bit outdated, but these are tried-and-true resources that I have recommended to many students and each has received positive feedback :) engVid - While the site itself is a bit messy and could definitely use a facelift, the content itself is gold. You can also find their videos on YouTube, where they are separated out into teacher-specific channels. The variety of teachers available is actually my favorite part of engVid! (See the teacher’s note below for why). Check out one of my favorite videos of theirs, about how stress changes meaning. Helps primarily with listening and grammar fundamentals.Membean - Hands down, my favorite online vocabulary resource. They do have paid plans that I also highly recommend for people preparing to take the SAT or GRE, but really it’s their extensive archive of roots that sets them apart. The way they explain roots and related words will turn you into a philologist no time! Helps primarily with vocabulary and reading.Duolingo - Okay, this one is an app, not a website, but it’s so good I had to include it. Education is rarely as addictive or effective as when it is gamified, and Duolingo does a good job of combining the bells and whistles that keep you crushing candy with the repetitive scaffolding that helps you improve retention. Helps with listening, reading, speaking, and writing. Yes, all of them.Breaking News English - Again, this site could definitely use a 2019 makeover, but the concept is great. Real news stories are curated and abridged to multiple levels of fluency, allowing learners to read about current events at a comfortable level. I recommend reading a story at a level that you are comfortable with, getting familiar with the content, and then reading the same article, but one level higher. Helps primarily with reading comprehension and vocabulary.Note from a teacher: As learners, we all have individual preferences regarding what kind of voices/personalities we like to listen to, what kind of content we enjoy reading/watching, etc. It’s important to identify and then cater to your own preferences in order to keep yourself engaged. If you try to force yourself to work through educational materials that don’t interest you, it will feel like just that - work. In my experience both as a teacher and language-learner, it’s imperative to find a way to learn that doesn’t feel like work, so be sure you experiment a bit and try to find enjoyable ways to immerse yourself in English. Let me know which of these you like, or what I should check out and add to my list!

What is the best way to learn English online for free? I assume that the person who asked this question is not a Digital Learner since he is still interested to learn online. Learning online was popular in the past. Today we should concentrate on mobile learning. Our mobile devices are ubiquitous and multimedia; they can do what teachers can’t. For example, mobile devices can create an environment for your subconscious training of English skills using multimedia comprehensible input that millions of learners can use 24/7 without the need of a teacher or a native speaker. Before I explain some pragmatic points of the mobile application I want to stress that adults experience frustration in learning English because conventional pedagogies dissect the language into individual components and teach reading, speaking, pronunciation, and grammar separately. This environment of Passive Learning and memorization is a wrong approach because a foreign language is not information to be remembered but a skill to be trained. The new pedagogy of subconsciously Training English skills allows simultaneous exercise of all language skills – reading, listening and speaking. If you want to avoid frustration, stop doing what you were doing for a long time with little success and follow the new approach that is described in this article: http://bit.ly/2y5fOcV Both teachers and students can start using Comprehensible multimedia input, based on simultaneous repetition, by simply downloading this Android application and allowing all learners to speak in the class concurrently using mobile devices and earphones. Learners located in China may download the Android application from this link: http://android.myapp.com/myapp/detail.htm?ADTAG=mobile&apkName=com.tencent.tmgp.net.lbt.ch.full Learners located in any other country may download the application from the Google Play Store: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=net.lbt.ch_full The training consists of speaking English texts aloud many times while simultaneously reading the text and listening to the recording.  The Android application lets learners share recorded sessions with friends or with a teacher. Content can be customized by the learner or the teacher. You can use the Android application for self-teaching as well as classroom instruction or guided online coaching. If you need more guidance when changing your thinking and implementing a new method of Training English skills, you may sign up for this online course: https://language-bridge-technology.teachable.com/

Given that so many online education resources have popped up in the last decade, it really seems like – as long as you want to learn – you can learn just about any skill on the internet. I’ll give you a rundown of the best English learning sites I’ve evaluated (most of them are free!), plus a few recommendations on courses to start out with for each. AlisonFounded in 2007, Alison is the original MOOC (massive open online course). The site has 750+ courses, but it focuses primarily on improving workplace skills. For example, they have courses dedicated to helping you get a new job or enhance your value if you’re looking to be promoted internally. With its diverse range of courses though, they really do have materials appropriate for any experience level of English learners. Here are the courses I’d recommend checking out first: Social English Language Skills: This course will help you improve your everyday English conversation.Introduction to English Grammar: As the title suggests, this course will help you improve your English grammar.MOOECMOOEC is short for Massive Open Online English Course, so you know it’s designed expressly for English learners. The courses range from beginner level to advanced English and are generally shorter than other MOOC websites. With other sites, it might take you several weeks to complete a class. Comparatively, many of MOOEC’s classes are single-study classes. If you’re not sure if online learning is right for you, I’d suggest starting off nice and easy with MOOEC. One note: MOOEC is an Australian-based company, so many of the courses discuss locations in Australia. Plus, pronunciation of some words may differ from American English. If you go ahead with MOOEC, here are the courses I’d recommend checking out first: Elementary English Course: If you have just started your English studies, this course is perfect for you.Common Mistakes: This course teaches you how to avoid English mistakes that happen all the time.Coffee Culture: If you are interested in Australian English or Australian culture specifically, you won’t want to miss this class!FutureLearn Most online courses can be completed independently, but FutureLearn actually encourages students of the same course to interact and communicate with their peers. With more than 1 million current users, you’d have plenty of opportunity to interact with other students! FutureLearn’s classes come from more than 40 countries and regions around the world, including some British institutions such as the British Council and the British Museum. Right now, there aren’t any partners from the United States contributing lessons. If your aim is to learn American English, you’d be better off with a different site. But Anglophiles (folks who really admire England) will probably fall in love with this website, starting with these courses: A Beginner’s Guide to Writing in English for University Study: A massive boon for anyone who is seeking to study abroad!Understanding IELTS – Techniques for English Language Tests: This course is very helpful for any type of English exam you might be preparing for, especially IELTS!Exploring English – Language and Culture: Great for learning more about British culture and improving your English!

Instead of website you can start the following method first for effective learning. “RLWS” Everyday R-Read Read good English newspaper/magazine (or) good books daily. Note down the new words into a separate note pad with meaning by help of dictionary. End of the week review all the new words you have noted down. L-Listen Listen audio’s from TED Talks, there you have the world class audios for various topics. Initial stage you can use subtitle in english to understand the conversation better and later on you will good to go without subtitles. W-Write Try writing essays every month with new words you have learned, it will increase your writing skill and also keeps those new words in your memory long time. S-Speak If you follow the first three steps this will be easier. Happy Learning !!!

I think the best way how to learn English (at least it worked my case) is to watch a videos in English (TV series, films, cartoons, TED talks, etc.) in a regular and repetitive manner. As a kid, I watched Cartoon Network hours a day. The TV station used to repeat all the episodes of different shows over and over again which helped me tremendously. I learned to use new words, English phrases and correct pronunciation very fast. Why? Because of repetitiveness. Today, I still often watch the same videos, or my favourite episodes. It may sound a little bit odd but I see in many cases that during a normal English conversation, I apply new word or a phrase automatically just because I heard it so many times in a show. Of course, you have a huge amount of different helpful tools, mobile apps, websites or books but this method had the greatest impact on me so far. Hope that helps. Cheers.

In general, language learning consists of at least four parts: listening, speaking, reading and writing. I will only answer the speaking part. My answer will encompass both free websites and apps. First, when we are kids, we learn how to speak by imitating what other people are saying. So the first things to do is to watch English speaking tutorials online and try to imitate. YouTube is probably the best free website where you can search for those tutorials. I would recommend BBC Follow me series as a starting point. Second, speaking requires practice. Try to speak to other English speaking people as much as you can. If you are having trouble finding people to practice, please see my answer in the following Quora link for free websites and apps that may help you find English speaking partners: How do I get an English speaking partner? Hope this helps.
